list.item: Half‐page vertical space above the heading for “Brussels” (p. ???).
Third‐page vertical space following the prose section for “Brussels” (p. ???).
Third‐page vertical space above the heading for “The Meuse” (p. ???).

Third‐page vertical space following the prose section for “The Meuse” (p. ???).; however, since a full‐page broadside copy—so far, unprecedented in its scale—of a scene from Proutʼs Facsimiles occupies the following page (p. ???), no vignette‐sized sketch may have been intended here. Just so, the verso following p. ??? containing the broadside (i.e., p. ???) is blank, and Ruskin may have intended nothing here, just as the versos of the large, full‐page lithographs in Proutʼs Facsimiles are blank. The following section, “Aix la Chapelle,” lacks a poem, but such verse presumably would not have preceded the heading and drawing for this section, which appear on p. ???.

Three‐quarters‐page vertical space, between the two final lines of prose section for “Aix la Chapelle” at the top of the page, and the two opening lines of the poem for “Cologne” at the bottom of the page (p. ???). This space might have been intended for a drawing related to “Cologne,” or for a poem related to the preceding section, “Aix la Chapelle.”.
Two‐line vertical space, as if two lines of the poem for “Cologne” are missing (p. ???), but if a vignette was projected for this space, its small size would have been unpecedented.
Quarter‐page vertical space following the prose section for “Cologne” (p. ???).
Two‐thirds‐page vertical space above the heading for “Andernacht” (p. ???).
Three‐quarters‐page vertical space following the prose section for “Andernacht” (p. ???).

Three‐quarters‐page vertical space following the poem for “Ehrenbreitstein,” which ends on the preceding verso, and above the opening four lines of prose for this section, at the bottom of this page (p. ???).
Half‐page vertical space above the poem for “St. Goar,” which itself lacks a heading (p. ???).
Quarter‐page vertical space following poem for “St. Goar” (p. ???), but this small space may have not been intended for a drawing.

Third‐page vertical space above the prose section for “St. Goar” (p. ???). At this place in the Library Edition, the editors do identify a “sketch of a town in a large plain, with distant mountains” (Works, 2:360 n. 1), but this appears to be an error. A drawing fitting that description appears instead on p. ???, in a space above the poem (which lacks a heading) for “Heidelberg,” where the editors do not note the presence of a drawing. It appears, therefore, that the editors simply misplaced their note on this drawing—unless at some point following their description, the slip with the drawing became detached and was reattached in the incorrect space.

On each of two facing pages (pp. ???), a half‐page vertical space below lines in the poem “Heidelberg”—following, respectively, “In the melee, or the tilt” (p. ???) and “Mimicking with motion dread” (p. ???).
Two full pages (pp. ????) and a half‐page vertical space (p. ???) above an opening fragment of prose for “Heidelberg” (“Most beautiful . . . sometimes”).
